file_metadata.title: Ion Channel and Pump Function in Planarian Regeneration

chunks.text: Regeneration, the process of recovering lost tissues through stem cell differentiation, was studied in planaria using a pharmacological screen. Inhibition of eag potassium channels disrupted regeneration initiation, while inhibiting the H+/K+-ATPase pump and minK potassium channel caused eye defects, suggesting the importance of potassium signaling and electrical potentials in regeneration.
chunks.chunk_summary: Potassium signaling and electrical potentials are crucial for planarian regeneration, as shown by a pharmacological screen.

chunks.text: Animal development and regeneration share similarities, both involving the replacement of tissues through stem cell differentiation.  Electrical polarity plays a role in both processes, influencing cell behavior in various cell types.  Studies have shown that an endogenous electric field is necessary for proper regeneration, and its reversal can reverse morphology.
chunks.chunk_summary: Electrical polarity is essential for regeneration and development, influencing cell behavior and morphology.

chunks.text: Ion gradients and electrical currents are essential for maintaining electrical polarity and may influence gene expression through several mechanisms. These include acting as positional information carriers, electrostatically attracting charged morphogens, and activating voltage-gated gap junctions for intercellular communication.  This study investigates the role of ion pumps, channels, and gap junctions in planarian regeneration.
chunks.chunk_summary: Ion gradients and currents are hypothesized to influence gene expression and play a crucial role in regeneration.

chunks.text: Planaria are a suitable model organism for regeneration studies due to their bilateral symmetry, cephalization, rapid regeneration, and amenability to molecular techniques.  Regeneration in planaria can be induced by cutting, with blastemas forming within two days and eyes appearing by the third day.  A pharmacological screen was used to identify pumps and channels crucial for regeneration, building on previous work in Xenopus embryos.
chunks.chunk_summary: Planaria are an ideal model for studying regeneration due to their rapid regeneration and amenability to molecular techniques.

chunks.text: Isogenic Dugesia japonica planaria were maintained in spring water at 22Â°C and fed organic chicken liver twice a week. Excess liver was removed after three hours, and the water was exchanged.
chunks.chunk_summary: Planaria were maintained under controlled conditions with regular feeding and water changes.

chunks.text: A pharmacological screen was conducted using a range of drugs targeting H+ and K+ pumps and channels. Drug concentrations were adjusted based on toxicity and phenotype observation. Mature planaria were cut into head, pharynx, and tail pieces to initiate regeneration and then placed in drug solutions. Controls were kept in spring water or 0.125% DMSO. Planaria were monitored for abnormal regeneration and imaged under a dissecting microscope.
chunks.chunk_summary: A pharmacological screen was used to assess the effects of various drugs on planarian regeneration, with careful monitoring and imaging.

chunks.text: DMSO produced a small but significant level of eye abnormalities in regenerating planaria, but it was ruled out as a confounding factor for DMT, PG, and HMR-1556 due to specific phenotypes or low DMSO concentrations.
chunks.chunk_summary: DMSO caused minor eye abnormalities but was not a confounding factor in the main drug experiments.

chunks.text: Dimethadione (DMT), a hERG potassium channel blocker, selectively caused the death of head and tail fragments but not trunk fragments, and inhibited blastema formation in surviving trunks. This effect was concentration-dependent and reversible upon removal of DMT. Whole planaria exposed to DMT died, suggesting a possible protective effect of the regenerative process in trunk segments.
chunks.chunk_summary: DMT inhibited regeneration in head and tail fragments, but not in trunk segments, suggesting a role for hERG channels in regeneration.

chunks.text: Prodigiosin (PG) at 0.125% caused eye defects, primarily cyclopia, in regenerating tail fragments, while higher concentrations were lethal and lower concentrations had no effect. HMR-1556, a Iks blocker, caused low levels of randomized eye defects at a specific concentration window, with higher and lower concentrations showing normal regeneration.
chunks.topic: Eye defects from PG and HMR-1556
chunks.chunk_summary: PG and HMR-1556 caused eye defects in regenerating planaria, suggesting a role for H+/K+-ATPase and Iks channels in eye development.

chunks.text: Several drugs, including skelid, NeM, SB-242784, THB, PHM, diazoxide, pinacidil, DIDS, DCCD, glycyrrhetinic acid, lindane, and arachidonic acid, did not produce aberrant regenerates in the planaria.
chunks.chunk_summary: A number of drugs did not affect planarian regeneration in this study.

chunks.text: The planarian pharmacological screen is an effective method for identifying ion channels and pumps crucial to regeneration, but it has limitations. Drug action on invertebrate homologs of vertebrate channels and pumps is not fully characterized, and negative results do not rule out involvement of the targeted channels and pumps in regeneration.
chunks.chunk_summary: While effective, the pharmacological screen has limitations due to the unknown effects of drugs on invertebrate homologs.

chunks.text: The eag potassium channel, a homolog of hERG, may be involved in regeneration.  DMT's effects on invertebrate eag homologs are not fully characterized.  Eag's role in generating a potassium flux for the global voltage gradient after injury, which could direct intercellular communication and anterior-posterior regeneration, needs further investigation.
chunks.chunk_summary: The eag potassium channel's role in regeneration, particularly in establishing a voltage gradient, requires further study.

chunks.text: Prodigiosin's inhibition of H+/K+-ATPase, previously implicated in left-right asymmetry, suggests its role in defining the left-right axis in planarian head regeneration. HMR-1556's effect on the KvLQT potassium channel, along with PG's effects, highlights the importance of potassium flux in eye development.  Further research using voltage imaging is suggested.
chunks.chunk_summary: Potassium channels, including H+/K+-ATPase and KvLQT, are important for eye development in planarian regeneration.

chunks.text: Research on electrical patterning in regeneration may provide insights into cancer and the effects of magnetic fields. Cancer cells differ from normal cells in ion content, ion channel expression, and proliferation control. The eag channel, potentially involved in controlling cell growth and morphology, warrants further investigation, especially given its reported overexpression in cancerous tissue. Magnetic fields, known to affect moving charges, may also influence development and require further study.
chunks.topic: Implications for cancer and magnetic fields
chunks.chunk_summary: Electrical patterning research may have implications for understanding cancer and the effects of magnetic fields on development.

chunks.text: This study used a pharmacological screen on planaria to identify the importance of potassium pumps and channels in regeneration, particularly in head regeneration. Dimethadione, prodigiosin, and HMR-1556, all targeting potassium channels or pumps, disrupted normal regeneration, highlighting the role of potassium flux in this process.
chunks.chunk_summary: Potassium flux, mediated by specific channels and pumps, is crucial for normal planarian regeneration, especially in the head.

chunks.text: This section lists the various drugs and their concentrations used in the pharmacological screen of planarian regeneration.
chunks.chunk_summary: A table lists the drugs and concentrations used in the study.
